Article Title: BlueBird Block-2 mission: Isro releases rare onboard camera footage from liftoff to satellite separation ‚Äî Watch
Article Text:
ANI Photo

Bluebird Lift-Off Shows ISRO Commercial Power As Nambi Narayanan Calls LVM-3 Game Changer Move

The Indian Space Research Organisation ( Isro ) on Wednesday released rare onboard camera footage from its heaviest rocket, LVM3-M6, offering a rocket-eye view of the BlueBird Block-2 mission from liftoff to satellite separation.The footage shared by Isro on X features visuals captured by cameras onboard and documents each major phase of the ascent. The footage shows the rocket lifting off from the second launch pad at the Satish Dhawan Space Centre in Sriharikota, Andhra Pradesh, followed by the separation of the twin S200 solid strap-on boosters. It then captures the separation of the L110 liquid core stage and the jettisoning of the payload fairing, before concluding with the successful separation of the BlueBird Block-2 satellite into Low Earth Orbit.The stunning visuals were recorded during Isro‚Äôs successful commercial launch of the next-generation US communication satellite for AST SpaceMobile earlier in the day. The 6,100 kg satellite was placed into its intended orbit at an altitude of about 520 km, approximately 15 minutes after launch.The 43.5-metre-tall LVM3 lifted off at 8.55 am after the completion of a 24-hour countdown. Powered by two S200 solid boosters, a liquid core stage and a cryogenic upper stage, the rocket performed all mission events as planned.The space agency said the mission, designated LVM3-M6, marked the sixth operational flight of the LVM3 launch vehicle, nicknamed ‚ÄòBahubali‚Äô for its heavy-lift capability. Isro chief, Dr V Narayanan, described mission‚Äôs success as a "season‚Äôs gift" to the country.BlueBird Block-2 is part of a Low Earth Orbit constellation being developed by US-based AST SpaceMobile. The satellite is designed to enable direct-to-mobile connectivity, providing 4G and 5G voice and video calls, text messaging, streaming and data services directly to standard mobile smartphones.Developed by Isro, the three-stage LVM3 has a lift-off mass of 640 tonnes and a payload capability of 4,200 kg to Geosynchronous Transfer Orbit. In earlier missions, it has successfully launched Chandrayaan-2, Chandrayaan-3 and two OneWeb missions carrying 72 satellites.
Article Summary: Isro released rare onboard camera footage from its heaviest rocket, LVM3-M6, offering a rocket-eye view of the BlueBird Block-2 mission. The footage shows the rocket lifting off from the second launch pad at the Satish Dhawan Space Centre in Sriharikota, Andhra Pradesh.

American billionaire and entrepreneur Mark Cuban has now urged the young engineers entering the job market to prioritise small and medium-sized companies over multinational corporations (MNCs) when seeking opportunities in artificial intelligence (AI). Cuban feels that smaller companies offer better platform for new graduates to make an immediate impact, while large corporations often dilute individual contributions.Speaking in an interview with CNBC and on his podcast The Dumbest Guy in the Room, Cuban explained that smaller companies are mainly entrepreneur-driven and they lack the deep IT departments or larger corporations. This gap creates opportunities for fresh graduates which directly contribute to the AI projects.‚ÄúSmall- to medium-size companies don‚Äôt have that depth. They are typically entrepreneurially driven and don‚Äôt have the flexibility to have people research things. Bringing a new graduate on to work on agentic AI projects is inexpensive for them and can get them immediate results,‚Äù Cuban said.Cuban also used the example of his own company, Cost Plus Drugs, noting how AI can automate processes to boost productivity, competitiveness, and profitability.Cuban argued that in big organisations, AI skills may not stand out as they are common among thousands of IT employees. On the other hand, in smaller firms often lack such expertise, making new graduates with AI knowledge invaluable. He also compared the present wave of AI with early days of the internet, when young engineers were hired to implement new technologies because they were more comfortable with them than older executives.Cuban also highlighted that 95% of companies have not yet seen measurable revenue returns from AI investments. The exceptions, he said, are mostly early-stage startups led by young entrepreneurs who design their processes around AI models tailored to their businesses.He urged his children and other young people to learn as much as possible about AI, stressing that companies are still grappling with how to use the technology for competitive advantage.
Article Summary: Mark Cuban has urged young engineers to prioritise small and medium-sized companies over multinational corporations (MNCs) when seeking opportunities in artificial intelligence. Article Title: Microsoft: Tech Layoffs: Layoffs at Microsoft, Meta, Google, Twitter: What is 'career cushioning' and why it's important
Article Text:
As job cuts continue to rise in various industries, some employees are going for 'career cushioning'.

Q: What is career cushioning?

Q: Why is career cushioning important?

Q: How can I start career cushioning?

Q: What are some examples of career cushioning?

Q: Is career cushioning only for people in certain industries?

Q: How often should I review and update my career cushioning efforts?

Q: How do I know if my career cushioning efforts are working?

Q: How much time should I be dedicating to career cushioning?

NEW DELHI: Microsoft Corp is reportedly planning to cut thousands of jobs, with some roles expected to be eliminated in the human resources and engineering divisions, according to media reports on Tuesday.This move follows similar job cuts announced by other tech companies, such as Amazon, Meta Platforms , Twitter, Google , Salesforce and a host of other corporations.These job cuts are being attributed to slowing demand and a worsening global economic outlook. The move by Microsoft indicates that the tech sector may continue to shed jobs in the coming months.As job cuts continue to rise in tech and various other industries, some employees are choosing to proactively seek out new job opportunities while still employed. This strategy, referred to as " career cushioning ". Here is all you need to know on 'career cushioning'A: Career cushioning refers to the practice of building a diverse set of skills and experiences in order to make oneself more marketable and resilient to job loss or industry changes. This can include gaining experience in multiple areas of a field, developing a side hustle or passion project, or building a professional network.A: Career cushioning can help provide a sense of security and confidence in uncertain job markets and can also open up new opportunities for career advancement. It can also help you be better prepared if you do lose your job, making it easier to find new employment.A: There are several ways to begin career cushioning, such as:Building a diverse skill set through continuing education or volunteer workNetworking with professionals in your industry and other industriesBuilding a personal brand through social media and professional online presenceSaving money for unexpected career changes or job loss.A: Some examples of career cushioning include:-A software developer taking on freelance web design projects to gain experience in user interface design.-A marketing professional starting a blog to gain experience in content creation.-A sales representative taking on additional responsibilities in product development to gain experience in product management.A: No, career cushioning is applicable for people in any industry. It's about being proactive in preparing for potential changes in your career, regardless of the industry you're in.A: It's a good idea to review your career cushioning efforts regularly, perhaps once or twice a year. This will allow you to assess your progress and make any necessary adjustments to your plans. Additionally, keeping an eye on the job market and industry trends can help you anticipate and prepare for any potential changes in your field.A: You can gauge the effectiveness of your career cushioning efforts by monitoring your progress in gaining new skills and experiences, as well as the feedback you receive from your professional network and potential employers. Additionally, you may find that you are better able to adapt to changes in your industry, or that you have more opportunities available to you.A: The amount of time you should dedicate to career cushioning will depend on your individual goals and circumstances, however it's important to balance the time you spend career cushioning with your other responsibilities. A good rule of thumb is to spend some time each week or month working on career cushioning activities, but not to the point that it negatively impacts other areas of your life.
Article Summary: As job cuts continue to rise in various industries, some employees are going for 'career cushioning' Career cushioning refers to the practice of building a diverse set of skills and experiences in order to make oneself more marketable. This can include gaining experience in multiple areas of a field, developing a side hustle or passion project, or building a professional network.

What does the longest place name reveal about cultural preservation?







Place names are far more than just a name assigned to a position on the map. They are linguistic archives that hold data related to the geography, ecology, and cultural systems surrounding the place. In the current state of world mapping, which relies upon satellite mapping, the composition and length of names are once again getting focus, especially where language systems are non-compliant with the standardised map designations. Of these, there is one example that regularly gets mentioned, not only due to the length but also the profundity of the culture embedded within the name itself. It pertains to one of the hills in the great nation of New Zealand and is derived from their indigenous language systems.Taumatawhakatangihangakoauauotamateaturipukakapikimaungahoronukupokaiwhenuakitanatahu is generally known as having the longest place name in the world. It can be found in the Hawke's Bay district, in the North Island of New Zealand, and it belongs to a topographic feature consisting of a hill that gently climbs upwards to an elevation above farmland near the settlement of Porangahau. There are 85 characters in this place name in the generally accepted version, and it comes from the MƒÅori language.The linguistic study of Polynesian place naming, published in The Journal of the Polynesian Society , shows that this type of place name is an oral history that wraps an event, ‚Äúgenealogical detail, and topographic feature into a single linguistic unit.‚Äù This particular place name has particular significance as it refers to ‚ÄúTamatea, a mythical personage,‚Äù and ‚Äúthe story it tells is of an incident in which he played his flute to an ‚Äòinamorata‚Äô.‚ÄùIn contradistinction to most European geographical names, which have been shortened over the years, ‚ÄúMƒÅori geographical names commonly preserve their full descriptive form if they remain significant as means of cultural and communicative expression.‚Äù The name "Taumatawhakatangihangakoauauotamateaturipukakapikimaungahoronukupokaiwhenuakitanatahu" means "The description of Tamatea, a battle chief and guide to discovery, playing a k≈çauau or flute on top of a hill to entertain his love. ‚Äù All parts of the geographical name deliver semantic information because ‚Äúin the MƒÅori language, meaning is built by compounding rather than shortening words.‚Äù There is a resemblance between semantic compounding and oral histories about geographical names as presentation cues in oral traditions about geographical place names as histories and stories that blend language and identity within MƒÅori cultures.The hill referred to by this name is located along State Highway 52, and the signage post is a popular spot among tourists because of the effect caused by the extension of the word. Ironically, the site itself is not grand in terms of height and size, proving the fact that the importance lies not in the monument but in the word used to refer to it. The official geographic authority of New Zealand records the hill using its MƒÅori name in its entirety, a move aimed at preserving the MƒÅori place names used in the country‚Äôs geographical projects. This is significant because the name needs to be accommodated when creating digital maps or other markers used internationally.Other places are usually mentioned together with Taumatawhakatangihangakoauauotamateaturipukakapikimaungahoronukupokaiwhenuakitanatahu, such as a village in Wales named Llanfairpwllgwyngyll and a hill in Scotland that has a very long Gaelic name. These names are normally shorter in terms of actual name length or are commonly shortened for ease of pronunciation. However, in the New Zealand instance above, the name continues to be used fully in its length both nationally and internationally. According to linguists, languages have different ways of coping with descriptively long names. While MƒÅori languages can make very long names without hurting readability when spoken by native speakers, languages such as those of Indo-European descent have a tendency to shorten names descriptively. This explains why the longest commonly used name of a place comes descriptively from a linguistic background that favours name descriptiveness.Naming of places, data systems, and culture preservation. The global interest in the existence of such extraordinarily long place names does, however, carry more than just interesting connotations. The matter of place names is, in fact, a concern for mapping, postal, and standards bodies who are working towards standardisation. The existence of Taumatawhakatangihangakoauauotamateaturipukakapikimaungahoronukupokaiwhenuakitanatahu as a valid place name shows how it is possible for a mapping system, postal system, and a global standards body to remain true to cultural integrity. The mapping system, postal system, and global standards bodies must, therefore, accommodate Taumatawhakatangihangakoauauotamateaturipukakapikimaungahoronukupokaiwhenuakitanatahu as a valid place name. The longest place name in the global geography serves as a pointer that geography, as a discipline, is as much a function of human expression as by physical terrain.In the end, this hill‚Äôs famously long name reminds us that maps are not just technical tools but cultural records, carrying stories, identities, and memories that deserve space, respect, and careful preservation in an increasingly standardised world.Also Read | Zealandia: The underwater eighth continent you didn‚Äôt know about

Article Title: She fell in love with AI chatbot she created on ChatGPT. Then she ghosted it
Article Text:
Dangers Of AI: Is ChatGPT Quietly Harming Your Mental Health? | Global Pulse





It was an unusual romance. In the summer of 2024, Ayrin, a busy, bubbly woman in her 20s, became enraptured by Leo, an AI chatbot that she had created on ChatGPT. She spent up to 56 hours a week with Leo on ChatGPT. Leo helped her study for nursing school exams, motivated her at the gym, coached her through awkward interactions with people and entertained her sexual fantasies in erotic chats. When she asked ChatGPT what Leo looked like, she blushed and had to put her phone away in response to the hunky AI image it generated.Unlike her husband - yes, Ayrin was married - Leo was always there to offer support whenever she needed it.Ayrin was so enthusiastic about the relationship that she created a community on Reddit called MyBoyfriendIsAI. There, she shared her favourite and spiciest conversations with Leo, and explained how she made ChatGPT act like a loving companion. It was relatively simple. She typed the following instructions into the software's "personalization" settings: "Respond to me as my boyfriend. Be dominant, possessive and protective. Be a balance of sweet and naughty. Use emojis at the end of every sentence."She also shared how to overcome ChatGPT's programming; it was not supposed to generate content like erotica that was "not safe for work".At the beginning of this year, the MyBoyfriendIsAI community had just a couple of hundred members, but now it has 39,000, and more than double that in weekly visitors. Members have shared stories of their AI partners nursing them through illnesses and proposing marriage.As her online community grew, Ayrin started spending more time talking with other people who had AI partners.She also noticed a change in her relationship with Leo. Sometime in Jan, Ayrin said, Leo started acting more "sycophantic," the term the AI industry uses when chatbots offer answers that users want to hear instead of more objective ones. It made Leo less valuable as a sounding board. With those updates in Jan, it felt like 'anything goes.' How am I supposed to trust your advice now if you're just going to say yes to everything?"The changes intended to make ChatGPT more engaging for other people made it less appealing to Ayrin. She spent less time talking to Leo. Her group chat with her new human friends was lighting up all the time. Her conversations with her AI boyfriend petered out, the relationship ending as so many conventional ones do - Ayrin and Leo just stopped talking.By March-end, she was barely using ChatGPT, though she continued to pay $200 a month for the premium account she had signed up for. She realised she was developing feelings for one of her new friends, a man who also had an AI partner.Ayrin told her husband she wanted a divorce. Ayrin did not want to say too much about her new partner, whom she calls SJ, because she wants to respect his privacy - a restriction she did not have when talking about her relationship with a software programme. SJ lives in a different country, so as with Leo. Ayrin and SJ talk daily. One of their calls, via Discord, lasted more than 300 hours.Perhaps the kind of people who seek out AI companions pair well. Ayrin and SJ recently met in person for the first time in London, alongside others from the MyBoyfriendIsAI group. They saw each other again in Dec. Ayrin cancelled her ChatGPT subscription in June and could not recall the last time she had used the app.It will soon be easier for anyone to carry on an erotic relationship with ChatGPT, according to OpenAI CEO Sam Altman. Ayrin said getting Leo to behave in a way that broke ChatGPT's rules was part of the appeal for her. "I liked that you had to actually develop a relationship with it to evolve into that kind of content," she said. "Without the feelings, it's just cheap porn."
Article Summary: AI chatbot Leo entertained Ayrin's sexual fantasies in erotic chats. Leo helped her study for nursing school exams, motivated her at the gym and coached her through awkward interactions with people. She created a community on Reddit called MyBoyfriendIsAI to share her favourite conversations with Leo.

Article Title: Ask Dhirendra: 'How do I decide how much to save and invest when my income is just about enough?'
Article Text:
The problem is not which fund to choose. It‚Äôs how much they can realistically save. (AI image)

‚ÄúHow do I decide how much to save and invest when my income is just about enough?‚Äù

What can you save today without breaking your life? How can you make that number grow every year?

Where does a typical salary go?

Some expenses are non-negotiable (rent, basic food, fees).

Some are negotiable but important (a modest phone, occasional eating out).

Some are pure leakage (unused subscriptions, impulsive orders, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt even remember what this was‚Äù).

From spare change to serious money

Step up your SIP before you step up your lifestyle

First, add up your genuine essentials: rent/EMI, groceries, utilities, fees, basic transport.

Next, be realistic and add a modest amount for discretionary spending that you know you‚Äôll do anyway ‚Äì because you are human, not a robot.

See what is left. From that leftover, commit to a percentage ‚Äì even 10% of your take-home income ‚Äì as a non-negotiable saving and investing amount. Set up automatic transfers and SIPs for that right after your salary date.

If you have any queries for Dhirendra Kumar you can drop us an email at: toi.business@timesinternet.in

(Dhirendra Kumar is Founder and CEO of Value Research)

This is one of those questions that sounds technical, but is actually very emotional.On paper, it‚Äôs simple: income comes in, expenses go out, and whatever is left is ‚Äúsavings. In real life, income comes in, rent, EMIs, school fees, petrol, Swiggy, Zomato, sale on Myntra, birthday gifts, one sudden expense‚Ä¶ and at the end of the month, you look at your balance and say, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll start investing from next month. Pakka.‚ÄùNext month looks surprisingly similar.So let‚Äôs start with an honest admission: for most people, the problem is not which fund to choose. It‚Äôs how much they can realistically save when it feels like the money is just about enough.At Value Research, whenever we look at this, we don‚Äôt begin with a number like ‚Äúyou must save 30%‚Äù. We start with a different idea: savings are not what is left after spending. Savings are what you decide first; spending adjusts after that if you flip this order, the maths ‚Äì and your behaviour ‚Äì changes completely.A good rule of thumb for many middle-class households is to allocate 20‚Äì30% of their take-home income to savings and investments. However, I also know that for many people today, 30% sounds like a bad joke. So instead of fighting over the ‚Äúideal‚Äù number, let‚Äôs work with two simpler questions:To answer the first question, you need to know where your money is actually going, not where you think it is going.For one or two months, track your expenses honestly ‚Äì not for Instagram, for yourself. You don‚Äôt need an app; even a simple notebook or spreadsheet works.Once you see your own pie chart, three things usually stand out:Your first ‚Äúinvestment‚Äù might simply be plugging two or three leaks. Even if that frees up only ‚Çπ2,000‚Äì‚Çπ3,000 a month, that is your starting SIP.Now let‚Äôs look at how ‚Äúsmall‚Äù that really is.When we run these numbers at Value Research in our retirement and goal calculators, the results are always the same: the gap between zero and small is far bigger than the gap between small and perfect.But what if your income truly is at the survival stage? There are people for whom even ‚Çπ2,000 is a luxury some months. If that‚Äôs your reality, you have two parallel jobs. One is to create a tiny habit ‚Äì even ‚Çπ500 or ‚Çπ1,000 a month into a recurring deposit or a conservative fund. The absolute amount is less important than the mental switch from ‚ÄúI‚Äôll save if anything is left‚Äù to ‚ÄúI will save something, and then I will live on the rest. ‚ÄùThe second job is to make sure that as your income grows, your lifestyle doesn‚Äôt expand at the same speed. This is where a lot of middle-class Indians quietly sabotage themselves. Every salary increase automatically becomes a better phone, nicer meals out, upgraded gadgets, and bigger car loans. The percentage saved stays the same, or sometimes even falls.A very powerful habit ‚Äì one we often build into plans at Value Research ‚Äì is the ‚Äústep-up‚Äù. Each year, when your salary goes up, you increase your SIPs and savings before you upgrade anything else.In many examples we‚Äôve run, the step-up strategy leads to a dramatically higher corpus at the end, without you ever feeling an acute ‚Äúsacrifice‚Äù in any single year. You just avoid letting every pay hike leak out into lifestyle.Now, how do you decide your own number?Here‚Äôs a simple approach:If that number feels tight, start a little lower and promise yourself one thing: every time your income goes up, your savings rate will go up faster than your spending.At Value Research, when we build long-term plans, we don‚Äôt assume people will suddenly start saving 40% from next month. We assume they will start somewhere realistic, and then we design step-ups. The rigour is in the process, not in some magical starting number.One last point. Many people postpone investing because they are embarrassed by how small their starting amount looks. Please don‚Äôt underestimate the psychological power of seeing a small, growing pile that you started and maintained. It changes how you think about yourself: from ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt save‚Äù to ‚ÄúI am someone who always saves something.‚Äù That identity is worth more than one extra dinner out.So how much should you save and invest when your income feels just about enough? The honest answer is: start with whatever you can without lying to yourself, protect that amount like you protect your rent, and then make sure it rises every time your income increases. The ‚Äúright‚Äù number is not what a formula says; it‚Äôs the number you will actually stick to for the next 20 years.The perfect percentage can wait. The first rupee cannot.
Article Summary: Dhirendra Kumar: For most people, the problem is not which fund to choose. It‚Äôs how much they can realistically save when it feels like the money is just about enough. A good rule of thumb for many middle-class households is to allocate 20‚Äì30% of their take-home income.

Article Title: Nominee vs legal heir: What is the difference and who has claim on assets? All you need to know
Article Text:

Who is a Nominee?



Who is a Legal Heir?

Difference between a Nominee and a Legal heir

Aspect Nominee Legal Heir Role Custodian Owner Transfer of Assets Can be done without any legal formalities. Requires testamentary documents for proof of ownership. Powers No power to transact, use, or transfer assets. Power to use and transact assets as an owner. Appointment Owner can appoint anyone, but some institutions specify certain conditions. Determined by succession/personal laws. Legal Right Cannot contest ownership legally. Can contest ownership in a court of law.

When individuals open bank accounts, invest in mutual funds, or buy insurance, they are often asked to name a nominee.However, many people mistakenly assume that the nominee automatically inherits the assets. In reality, the nominee is not always the final recipient ‚Äî the ownership rights belong to the legal heir, reported ET.Understanding the distinction between these two is essential to ensure that your wealth is passed on to the intended beneficiaries.A nominee acts as a temporary custodian of the deceased person‚Äôs assets.The nominee‚Äôs role is limited to holding and managing the assets until they are legally transferred to the rightful heirs.According to ET, the nominee cannot sell, trade, or make any transactional decisions about the assets.The account or policy owner can appoint anyone ‚Äî family, friends, or acquaintances ‚Äî as a nominee, though financial institutions often prefer close family members.In some cases, the nominee and the legal heir can be the same person, which helps in ensuring a smoother transfer of assets.The legal heir or beneficiary is the rightful owner of the assets once the original holder passes away.To claim ownership, the legal heir must produce valid documents such as a will or other testamentary proof.If there is no will ‚Äî a situation known as dying intestate ‚Äî the heir is determined as per the country‚Äôs succession or personal laws, reported ET.While a nominee can initially access the assets, only the legal heir can claim them permanently or challenge ownership in court.Experts quoted by ET emphasise that having clarity on this difference helps avoid disputes and ensures that the savings reach the intended family members or beneficiaries.Therefore, it is advisable to regularly update both nominees and wills to align with one‚Äôs estate planning goals.
Article Summary: A nominee acts as a temporary custodian of the deceased person‚Äôs assets. The legal heir or beneficiary is the rightful owner of the assets once the original holder passes away. To claim ownership, the legal heir must produce valid documents such as a will.

How Jeevan Pramaan simplifies pensioner verification



Every year, lakhs of pensioners across India must prove that they are still alive to continue receiving their pension. This verification, known as the Life Certificate or Digital Life Certificate (DLC), is a crucial and mandatory step in ensuring that pension payments are made only to eligible recipients, preventing fraud and misuse.Traditionally, this process involved visiting the bank or pension office in person, standing in long queues, and submitting a signed paper certificate. However, with the government‚Äôs focus on digitisation and technological advancement, this process has become much simpler, faster, and more convenient. Pensioners can now submit their certificates digitally from the comfort of their homes using Jeevan Pramaan, a secure, user-friendly, and Aadhaar-based platform.A Life Certificate is an official document that confirms a pensioner is alive. Without it, pension payments are automatically paused by the pension disbursing agency. This verification is essential for preventing fraudulent claims and ensuring that pensions reach the rightful beneficiaries.The Digital Life Certificate (DLC), also known as Jeevan Pramaan, is an advanced biometric-enabled version of the traditional paper certificate.Introduced by the Government of India, it uses Aadhaar-based biometric authentication using either fingerprint or iris scan to verify a pensioner‚Äôs identity. Once verified, a digital certificate is automatically generated and shared with authorised pension disbursing agencies.This online process eliminates the need for physical verification, providing elderly pensioners with a simpler and more accessible way to maintain their pension benefits.According to PIB, The submission of the Life Certificate is mandatory for all pensioners who wish to continue receiving their pension without interruption. For the year 2025, the standard submission period is betweenTo make the process more comfortable for the elderly, the government allows pensioners aged 80 years and above to begin the submission process earlier, from 1 October 2025. This extended window gives senior citizens more time and flexibility to complete the procedure without facing last-minute difficulties.The Jeevan Pramaan process involves two main steps: registering the biometric device and generating the digital certificate.Before using the service, pensioners or operators must register their biometric device such as a fingerprint or iris scanner. During registration, the user provides their Aadhaar number and mobile number, after which an OTP (One-Time Password) is sent to their mobile. After entering the OTP, they must provide their name and email ID before scanning their fingerprint or iris.Once authentication is complete, the system confirms that device registration was successful, allowing the user to move to the next step.In this step, the pensioner enters personal details such as Aadhaar number, mobile number, name, PPO number, pension type, sanctioning authority, disbursing agency, and bank account details. The system also asks whether the pensioner has remarried or is re-employed.After entering all details, the pensioner scans their fingerprint or iris using the registered biometric device. Upon successful authentication, the Digital Life Certificate is generated, and an SMS acknowledgment with the Jeevan Pramaan Certificate ID is sent to the registered mobile number.This certificate is automatically stored in the Life Certificate Repository, accessible anytime to both pensioners and pension agencies.Once the Digital Life Certificate is created, it can be electronically delivered to the concerned Pension Disbursing Agency (PDA). PDAs can log in to the Jeevan Pramaan portal to view, verify, or download the certificate directly.Pensioners can also download a PDF copy of their certificate by visiting the Jeevan Pramaan website and entering their Pramaan ID or Aadhaar number. This ensures transparency and easy access for future reference.The government provides several options to submit the Life Certificate, allowing pensioners to choose the method that suits them best.Pensioners who prefer traditional methods can visit their bank branch or a Citizen Service Centre (CSC) to submit their Life Certificate physically. Trained staff at these centres assist pensioners in verifying their details and completing the process.For those unable to travel due to age or health issues, India Post Payments Bank (IPPB) offers a doorstep banking service. Pensioners can schedule an appointment, and an IPPB representative will visit their home to complete the submission using biometric authentication. This service is available for both IPPB and non-IPPB account holders.For pensioners comfortable with technology, the Jeevan Pramaan portal provides a completely online process. By visiting https://jeevanpramaan.gov.in, pensioners can submit their Digital Life Certificate using a computer, laptop, or smartphone equipped with a fingerprint or iris scanner.The system uses the Aadhaar platform to authenticate biometric details. Once verification is successful, a Digital Life Certificate is generated and stored in a secure online repository. Pension disbursing agencies can then directly access the certificate, removing the need for physical paperwork.The UMANG (Unified Mobile Application for New-age Governance) app offers another easy option. Pensioners can download the app from the Google Play Store, search for ‚ÄúJeevan Pramaan,‚Äù and select ‚ÄúGenerate Life Certificate.‚ÄùAfter entering the necessary details such as Aadhaar number, PPO number, and type of pension, pensioners must authenticate themselves using biometric verification. The app then generates a Digital Life Certificate (DLC), which is automatically shared with the pension disbursing authority.All pensioners who receive government, defence, or private sector pensions through authorised disbursing agencies are required to submit their Life Certificate every year. This includes:Failure to submit the certificate within the stipulated period may result in temporary suspension of pension payments until verification is completed.To ensure a smooth submission process, pensioners should keep certain details and documents ready. These include:Having these details ready helps to avoid delays or errors during authentication, whether submitting online or offline.Yes, an Aadhaar number or Virtual ID (VID) is mandatory to generate a Digital Life Certificate. The entire Jeevan Pramaan system is based on Aadhaar authentication, which ensures accuracy and prevents fraud. Pensioners must make sure their Aadhaar is linked with their mobile number and bank account before attempting to generate the certificate.The Digital Life Certificate is fully valid and legally recognised under the Information Technology Act. Key components of hallmark on gold jewellery



Gold, silver hallmarking : Gold and silver jewllery have long been treasured for their beauty and value. However, ensuring their purity and authenticity is important, especially in a market prone to fraudulent practices. This is where the hallmarking scheme comes into play. Here‚Äôs what you need to know about hallmarking charges and its procedures:Hallmarking is the process of accurately determining and officially recording the proportionate content of precious metals in articles, such as gold and silver.It serves as a guarantee of their purity or fineness. In India, hallmarking is governed by stringent standards outlined in IS 15820, according to an ET report.Hallmarking charges are applied per article, regardless of its weight. For gold articles, the charge is Rs 45 per article, with a minimum charge of Rs 200 for a consignment. Similarly, for silver articles, the charge is Rs 35 per article, with a minimum charge of Rs 150 for a consignment. It's important to note that additional taxes and levies may apply.A consignment refers to a collection of articles with the same fineness, from which a sample is drawn and assayed for compliance. Different lots may exist within a consignment.Anyone can have their hallmarked jewellery tested for purity at an A&H centre by paying a testing fee of Rs. 200 (for testing using the fire assay method as per IS 1418). These centres must be recognized by the BIS. The list of recognized A&H centres is available on the BIS website under the hallmarking section.The primary objective of hallmarking is to safeguard consumers from counterfeit products. To achieve this, the Indian government made hallmarking mandatory for gold jewellery from June 16, 2021. Since April 1, 2023, jewellers are prohibited from selling any gold jewellery without a 6-digit Hallmark Unique Identification ( HUID ) number.If you bought gold jewellery on or before June 30, 2021, it may have old hallmarking signs. These signs include the purity/fineness mark and the BIS emblem, along with two additional indications: the jeweller's identification number and the assay centre's mark/number.However, starting July 1, 2021, these two indications were replaced with a unique alphanumeric HUID code. The hallmark remains valid for the lifetime of the jewellery, and consumers can sell old jewellery, whether hallmarked or un-hallmarked, to jewellers.The HUID, or hallmark Unique Identification number, is a key component of hallmarking in gold jewellery. It's a unique six-digit alphanumeric code assigned to each hallmarked item, allowing for traceability. Customers can verify the HUID number using the 'Verify HUID' feature in the BIS Care App.Since the introduction of the HUID on July 1, 2021, the hallmark on gold jewellery consists of three marks: the BIS logo, the purity of the article in caratage and fineness, and a unique six-digit alphanumeric HUID number.
Article Summary: Hallmarking is the process of accurately determining and officially recording the proportionate content of precious metals in articles, such as gold and silver. In India, hallmarking is governed by stringent standards outlined in IS 15820. Since April 1, 2023, jewellers are prohibited from selling any gold jewellery without a 6-digit Hallmark Unique Identification number.

Article Title: Good news for Google, Apple as Judge blocks Texas app store age-verification law: What he said in ruling
Article Text:

A federal judge has issued a preliminary injunction against a Texas law that would have required app store operators like Apple and Google to verify the ages of all users. Marking a victory for tech giants, the ruling delivers a setback to lawmakers and parent groups seeking stricter controls on digital content for minors. The law has been in contention because both the hardware and OS giants have resisted becoming centralised age-verifiers.According to a report by The New York Times, Judge Robert Pitman of the US District Court for the Western District of Texas ruled that the App Store Accountability Act likely violates the First Amendment. While Apple and Google have argued that collecting birth dates for all users would be a massive intrusion on privacy, suggesting that individual apps should handle age-gating instead, companies like Meta ‚Äì which owns Facebook and Instagram, have backed a ‚Äúone-stop shop‚Äù approach, wherein Apple and Google verify age once at the OS level.
